content.text: Calculate the mass of the load
mass =
Fig. 1.1 shows the load suspended from the thread
A wire is attached to the load at point X and pulled horizontally to the right
The tension in the horizontal wire is 1.2N
By drawing a scale diagram or by calculation, determine:
• the magnitude of the resultant of the force at X due to the load and due to the tension in the wire
• the direction of the resultant relative to the vertical direction
Show your working
magnitude of resultant force = .........N
Forces may produce changes in the size and the shape of an object
State two other changes that forces may produce
A load is suspended from a thread. The vertical force on the thread due to the load is 0.75N
Define acceleration
Calculate the time taken for the train to increase its speed from \(15\mathrm{m / s}\) to \(28\mathrm{m / s}\)
Calculate the force required to produce an acceleration of \(1.1 \text{m/s}^2\) for this train
The train uses electric motors
Explain why the force on the train due to the motors is greater than the value calculated in (ii)
A train has a total mass of \(520000\mathrm{kg}\). The train accelerates at \(1.1\mathrm{m / s}^2\)
Describe the transfers of energy of the ball between stores from when the ball begins to fall to when it reaches the ground
Calculate the maximum speed of the ball. Ignore air resistance
Show your working
maximum speed = .........

State two ways that evaporation differs from boiling
Determine the temperature of the liquid oxygen in K
temperature = .........K

State two methods of thermal energy transfer that a vacuum prevents

The temperature of the liquid oxygen is \(-160^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)

The critical angle for the glass is \(42^{\circ}\)

State two advantages of using optical fibres to transmit data

On Fig. 6.1:
- label one point C to indicate a compression
- label one point R to indicate a rarefaction
Explain why this graph **cannot** be used to find the wavelength of the sound wave
The sound becomes louder and of lower pitch
State what happens to:
the amplitude of the sound
the frequency of the sound
A sound wave travels through air. Fig. 6.1 shows a pressure–time graph for the air at one place
A sound of frequency \(13\mathrm{kHz}\) is transmitted through water
The speed of sound in water is \(1500\mathrm{m / s}\)
Calculate the wavelength of this sound in water
wavelength = .........
State the approximate speed of sound in air
Fig. 7.1 shows three bars of steel, A, B and C
A student is given the three pieces of steel. Two of the pieces are magnetised and one piece is unmagnetised
Describe and explain how the student determines which piece is unmagnetised using only the three pieces of steel
The mains voltage supplied to the transformer is \(240\mathrm{V}\). The output power of the transformer is \(45\mathrm{W}\). The transformer is \(100\%\) efficient
Calculate the input current to the transformer
input current = .........
Draw a labelled diagram of a step-down transformer. On the labels, state a suitable material for each of the components
Fig. 7.2 shows a circuit diagram of a step-down transformer
On Fig. 8.1, draw the circuit symbol for a voltmeter used to measure the potential difference (p.d.) across the light-dependent resistor (LDR).
The surroundings change from light to dark
1. State the effect of this change on the resistance of the LDR
2. State and explain the effect of this change on the p.d. across the light-emitting diode (LED)
Fig. 8.1 shows a circuit. The circuit is designed to switch on a night light when the surroundings are dark
Fig. 8.2 shows another circuit. Lamps A and B are identical filament lamps
The current supplied by the power supply is 0.50A
Calculate the resistance of lamp A
resistance = .........
State and explain **two** safety precautions necessary for the use of these isotopes in medical procedures
safety procedure 1
explanation
safety procedure 2
explanation
Give **two** reasons why alpha-emitters are **not** used as radioactive tracers inside the body
Radioactive isotopes that emit ionising radiation are used in hospitals
Sodium-24 is an isotope of sodium (Na) that has a proton number of 11 and a nucleon number of 24
Sodium-24 decays by emission of a beta-particle to form an isotope of magnesium (Mg)
Use nuclide notation to write down the nuclide equation for this decay
The Solar System includes the Sun and planets
State two other types of natural object that orbit the Sun
State the shape of the orbits of the planets
Fig. 10.1 shows the orbit of an object around the Sun. At point A, the object is closest to the Sun. At point B, the object is furthest away from the Sun
State and explain the energy transfer as the object travels from point A to point B
statement
explanation
Jupiter is \(7.8 \times 10^{11} \text{m}\) from the Sun. The speed of light in a vacuum is \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\)
Calculate the time taken for light from the Sun to reach Jupiter
time =
Name the galaxy that contains the Sun
Light observed from distant galaxies is redshifted
State the theory of the Universe that this observation supports
State when this radiation was produced
Explain why this radiation is now in the microwave region of the electromagnetic spectrum
Cosmic microwave background radiation (CMBR) is observed at all points in space
